Award.AwardTitle: Characterizing the Stars and Galaxies that Drove Reionization
Award.AbstractNarration:
Adam Beardsley is awarded an NSF Astronomy and Astrophysics Postdoctoral Fellowship to conduct a program of research and education at Arizona State University. Beardsley will analyze data from large arrays of radio telescopes to detect hydrogen atoms from a time when the first stars formed in the Universe. Studying that period in cosmic history is important because it influenced the formation of objects such as galaxies and black holes. Alongside this research, Beardsley will train college students to design a low-cost radio telescope adaptable to high school and college classrooms, and he will conduct public outreach about radio astronomy with participation from these students.

Beardsley proposes to detect the highly redshifted 21-cm line of intergalactic hydrogen from the Epoch of Reionization (EoR). By developing an imaging-based analysis pipeline for the Hydrogen Epoch of Reionization Array experiment, Beardsley seeks to obtain the first 21-cm EoR power spectrum detection and thus constrain models of reionization. Beardsley will also identify other probes of reionization by combining the 21-cm measurements with infrared galaxy surveys. For the educational component of his work, Beardsley will train undergraduate students to update the Very Small Radio Telescope (VSRT) program. He will also conduct astronomy outreach events featuring the students' work with the VSRT.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The scientific goals of this project were to utilize two complimentary radio observatories to constrain the astrophysical processes that drove the ionization of the universe, and to explore new science directions enabled by multi-wavelength studies.

We published several articles exploring the tradeoffs of different analysis techniques which has impact on immediate results and will inform future telescope designs. Using the Murchison Widefield Array (MWA), two papers were published with upper-limits on the strength of the 21cm signal from reionization. Each was the the best limit at the time. We proposed an experimental observing mode for the MWA to expand its field of view for foreground modeling. We recorded over 100 hours of observations and the data are being analyzed, but early calibration and imaging results are promising. This mode is now being used for triggered transient observations to increase the sky coverage when the specific location of the event is not immediately known.

Work on the Hydrogen Epoch of Reionization Array (HERA) focused on the commissioning the array and developing algorithms for evaluating data quality and excising contamination from man-made interference. Analysis of early data resulted in characterization of the system performance and fed back into the construction of the array.

Methods to tie together radio observations with other wavelengths were explored through simulations. The scientific potential of these future experiments was summarized in a paper submitted to the 2020 Astronomical Decadal Review.  

Technologies to support future radio arrays with thousands of elements were developed using the Long Wavelength Array. We deployed a back-end system that produces full-sky radio images at extremely high time resolution. While motivated by future cosmology experiments, this technology will enable current radio transient science as well.

The broader impacts of this project were broadening STEM participation by providing mentored research experiences to non-traditional and underrepresented undergraduates, and the development of a platform for classrooms to build their own small-scale radio telescope. The Completely Hackable Amateur Radio Telescope (CHART) is intended to be an accessible way for students and hobbyists to explore a variety of concepts from astronomy to electronics and data analysis. We reach a broad audience by designing a low cost platform and providing tutorials.
